practice_cycles.focus_summary: Core UI Paradigms and Basic State Management
practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase provides the necessary structural grounding for your advancement into mobile engineering by focusing your efforts on the core UI paradigms and layout architectures that distinguish mobile platforms from traditional web environments, which is essential because failing to master the specific lifecycle events and touch-based interaction patterns early on will lead to significant technical debt and frustration when you eventually attempt to integrate complex data streams and backend services into your applications at the intermediate level.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Translating design mockups into responsive component hierarchies
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Mapping local UI state to interactive elements

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Creating static screens and basic linear navigation
difficulty_profile.challenging: Implementing complex flex-based layouts and handling platform-specific UI differences

objective: Replication of a multi-screen prototype without tutorial assistance
Successful implementation of data-passing between three distinct views
subjective: Decreased frustration when troubleshooting layout alignment issues

objective: Average time spent per feature implementation
Ratio of build-time errors to runtime errors
Consistency of code style across projects
subjective: Clarity of the mental model for data flow within an app

architect_notes: Your 9-hour weekly allocation is best split into three 3-hour sessions to allow for deep focus.
Avoid switching between different frameworks (e.g., Swift and Flutter) during this initial cycle.
Focus on understanding why a component renders before moving to complex animations.

practice_logs.activity: Translating design mockups into responsive component hierarchies
